open-answer:
The Skipper, also referred to as Captain O'Hara, is the captain of the spaceship Leo. He is described as a bit of a sybarite and is in command of the ship during its mission to run the Outer Planets Alliance blockade and reach Jupiter's fourth satellite, Callisto. The Skipper is responsible for hiring Andy Laney, the new cook, and interacts with him throughout the story.


The new chef in the input article is Andy Laney, a slim, trim, natty little Earthman not more than five-foot-two in height, with a smooth-cheeked young face and a high-pitched, but not unpleasant voice. He is hired as a cook on the spaceship Leo and is referred to as "Captain Slops" throughout the story.


The heat-cannon is an old Nolan heat cannon that was rusting in the storeroom of the ship Leo. It is mentioned in the following paragraphs:

- "There's an old Nolan heat-cannon rusting in the storeroom. If that could be installed by the galley vent, I could use it as an incinerator."
- "During the night watch two men of the crew lugged the ancient Nolan heat cannon from stores and I went below to check. I found young Slops bent over the old cannon, giving it a strenuous and thorough cleaning."
- "I said, "Hold everything, Slops! You can't do that! It's against regulations. Code 44, Section xvi, says, 'Fixed armament shall be placed only in gunnery embrasures insulated against the repercussions of firing charges, re-radiation, or other hazards accruent to heavy ordnance.'"
- "I had finished my inspection, and I sniggered as his words reminded me of a joke I'd heard at a spacemans' smoker."


The decision to allow the new chef to use the heat-cannon as an incinerator was influenced by several factors:

1. The ship's need for a cook: The crew was desperate for a cook, and the new chef, Andy Laney, volunteered for the job. The captain was willing to accommodate his requests to ensure the crew was well-fed and in top physical condition for their mission.

2. The chef's culinary skills: Andy Laney proved to be an excellent cook, preparing delicious meals for the crew. This made the captain more inclined to fulfill his request for an incinerator to improve the galley's waste disposal system.

3. The promise of a special banquet: Andy Laney mentioned that he was planning a special banquet with roast marsh-duck and pinberry pie, which the captain was particularly fond of. The captain's desire for this meal made him more willing to bend the rules and allow the installation of the heat-cannon as an incinerator.

4. The lack of proper equipment: The ship did not have the necessary equipment to install a proper incinerator, but Andy Laney suggested using the old Nolan heat-cannon as a makeshift solution. The captain agreed to this unconventional approach to solve the waste disposal issue in the galley.

The event where the new chef, Andy Laney, uses the heat-cannon as an incinerator occurs when he requests Captain O'Hara to install an old Nolan heat-cannon in the galley to dispose of garbage. Despite Lieutenant Dugan's warning that it is against regulations, Captain O'Hara agrees to the installation, enticed by the promise of a special banquet featuring roast marsh-duck and pinberry pie. Andy Laney cleans and prepares the heat-cannon for use as an incinerator, assuring the captain and Dugan that he will be careful with it.

open-answer:
Duane and Stevens are two characters in the story "Conspiracy on Callisto" by James MacCreigh. Duane is the protagonist who wakes up with amnesia and is accused of killing Stevens, a white-haired man. They both seem to be involved in a gun-running operation, supplying weapons to Governor Andrias on Callisto. Duane is struggling to remember his past and understand his role in the events unfolding around him, while Stevens is killed in an accident during a course change on their spaceship.

The event involving the course change announcement occurs when Peter Duane and the white-haired man, Stevens, are arguing in the ship's corridor. During their heated argument, the public announcement (P.A.) speaker blares something unintelligible, which neither man pays attention to. A muted alarm bell then sounds through the P.A. speakers, signaling a one-minute warning for the course change. The ship reaches the midpoint of its flight, and the bells warn everyone on board to take shelter and strap themselves in their pressure bunks against the deadly stress of acceleration as the ship reverses itself and begins to slow its headlong plunge into Callisto. However, Duane and Stevens do not heed the warning and continue their struggle, resulting in them being caught off-guard and injured when the course change occurs.

Pressure bunks are mentioned in the following paragraph: "The small steering rockets flashed briefly. The men were thrust bruisingly against the side of the corridor as the rocket spun lazily on its axis. The side jets flared once more to halt the spin, when the one-eighty turn was completed, and the men were battered against the opposite wall, still weightless, still clinging to each other, still struggling." 

Pressure bunks are a safety feature in spaceships, designed for passengers and crew to strap themselves in during high acceleration or course changes to protect them from the potentially deadly stress and forces experienced during such maneuvers.

Duane and Stevens did not go to the pressure bunks when the course change was announced because they were engaged in a heated argument over the division of payment for their cargo. They were so focused on their disagreement that they ignored the warning bells and continued their confrontation, ultimately leading to a physical struggle between them. This distraction caused them to miss the opportunity to secure themselves in the pressure bunks, resulting in them being caught in the dangerous acceleration forces during the course change.

open-answer:
Tr'en are an alien race in the story, characterized by their green appearance, cat-like pupils, and fifty-eight pointed teeth. They are highly efficient, logical, and scientifically advanced, having developed technologies such as hypnopædic language courses and lie-detector machines. The Tr'en are on the verge of developing space travel and faster-than-light travel, which could potentially make them a threat to the rest of the galaxy. Their society is governed by a single Ruler, who is adopted by the previous Ruler to ensure continuity and stability.


Korvin is the protagonist of the story, a human who has crash-landed on the planet of the Tr'en. He is a captive of the Tr'en and is subjected to their questioning and lie-detector tests. His mission is to prevent the Tr'en from becoming a threat to the rest of the galaxy by confusing them with the concept of democracy, which they cannot understand due to their highly logical and efficient nature.


"You are Korvin," he said.

"You are of the Tr'en," he replied. The green being nodded.

"I am Didyak of the Tr'en," he said. Amenities over with, he relaxed slightly—but no more than slightly—and came into the cell, closing the door behind him. Korvin thought of jumping the Tr'en, but decided quickly against it. He was a captive, and it was unwise to assume that his captors had no more resources than the ones he saw: a small translucent pistollike affair in a holster at the Tr'en's side, and a small knife in a sheath at the belt. Those Korvin could deal with; but there might be almost anything else hidden and ready to fire on him.

"What do you want with me?" Korvin said. The Tr'en speech—apparently there was only one language on the planet—was stiff and slightly awkward, but easily enough learned under drug hypnosis; it was the most rigorously logical construction of its kind Korvin had ever come across. It reminded him of some of the mathematical metalanguages he'd dealt with back on Earth, in training; but it was more closely and carefully constructed than even those marvels.

"I want nothing with you," Didyak said, leaning against the door-frame. "You have other questions?"

Korvin sighed. "What are you doing here, then?" he asked. As conversation, it wasn't very choice; but it was, he admitted, better than solitude.

"I am leaning against the door," Didyak said. The Tr'en literalist approach to the smallest problems of everyday living was a little hard to get the hang of, Korvin told himself bitterly. He thought for a second.

"Why did you come to me?" he said at last.

Didyak beamed at him. The sight was remarkably unpleasant, involving as it did the disclosure of the Tr'en fifty-eight teeth, mostly pointed. Korvin stared back impassively. "I have been ordered to come to you," Didyak said, "by the Ruler. The Ruler wishes to talk with you."

It wasn't quite "talk"; that was a general word in the Tr'en language, and Didyak had used a specific meaning, roughly: "gain information from, by peaceful and vocal means." Korvin filed it away for future reference. "Why did the Ruler not come to me?" Korvin asked.

"The Ruler is the Ruler," Didyak said, slightly

The relationship between Tr'en's response and Korvin's behavior in the story is that the Tr'en's logical and scientific mindset makes them vulnerable to Korvin's strategy of confusing them with the concept of democracy. Korvin's behavior is driven by his mission to neutralize the threat posed by the Tr'en, and he uses their own strengths against them by presenting them with a seemingly paradoxical concept that they cannot comprehend. This keeps the Tr'en occupied with trying to understand democracy, preventing them from focusing on space exploration and conquest. The Tr'en's response to Korvin's behavior highlights their inability to grasp the idea of a democratic government, which ultimately helps Korvin achieve his mission.

Ro is a young Martian man who is the protagonist of the story. He is returning home after exploring the north and is eager to reunite with his family and his love interest, Na. Ro is skilled in climbing and fighting, and he is determined to avenge the death of his father and brothers at the hands of the Oan, a race of rat-like creatures. He rescues a group of white-skinned people from Earth who have been captured by the Oan and enlists their help in his quest for revenge.

In the input article, the woman referred to is Na, a Martian woman who is Ro's love interest and chosen mate. She is mentioned throughout the story, particularly in the following paragraphs:

- "He was anxious to see his family again, his father and mother and all his brothers and sisters; to sit round a fire with them at the entrance to their cave and tell of the wondrous places he'd visited. And, most of all, he wanted to see Na, graceful, dark-eyed Na, whose fair face had disturbed his slumber so often, appearing in his dreams to call him home."
- "For a long moment Ro studied the approaching creatures. Then he gasped in surprise. The pursued was a young woman, a woman he knew. Na! The pursuer was a squat, ugly rat man, one of the vicious Oan who lived in the cliffs."
- "He took a pouch from his waist and shook out a gold arm band. This he clasped on Na's wrist. 'All men will know now that you are the mate of Ro,' he whispered. And he kissed her, as was the custom of his tribe when a man took a wife."
- "Na met him at the entrance. She was returning from a clump of trees a short distance away. Her arms were loaded with Manno, the fruit of Mars, and clusters of wild berries and grapes. 'You see,' she said, 'I will make you a good mate. Our table will be well provided for.'"

Additionally, there is another woman mentioned in the story, Charlotte, who is a member of the Earth expedition and Carlson's love interest. She is mentioned in the following paragraphs:

- "There were two more white ones who came from the sphere. One was a woman with golden hair, and the other, a man of age, with hair like silver frost."
- "Ro noticed that Charlotte had slept beside Carlson, but moved away shyly now that it was daylight. He noticed, too, that Grimm was seeing the same thing and seemed annoyed."
- "Carlson seemed to come out of a trance. He swung around to trail Ro up the sloping part of the mountain. They climbed in silence."
- "Carlson straightened. He weighed Ro's words before answering. Finally he said, 'I didn't want to make trouble. It was a bad time, and senseless, besides. Charlotte and I are planning to be married when we return to America. It's not as though Grimm was still in

The reason behind Ro's behavior of telling the woman not to move is to ensure their safety and the success of their plan. Ro wants to rescue the white men from Earth who have been captured by the Oan and fight the Oan to avenge the death of his father, brothers, and the men of his tribe. By instructing Na and the white men to stay still and not move until he gives a signal with his thoughts, Ro aims to avoid detection by the Oan and execute their plan without any complications.

The valley has a narrow entrance, which is about a hundred yards long and twenty feet wide, with almost straight cliff walls on both sides.

As a consequence of the white men choosing to sleep in the valley instead of the Martian caves, they were captured by the Oan, a race of rat men. The Oan then used the white men's weapons to attack the Martians, forcing them to leave their caves. In the input article, the event where Jonathan feels ashamed occurs when he is captured by the twenty-seven young women after trying to escape from them. When Jonathan and Ann are arguing about going back to the space ship to get cigarettes, a second girl named Olga suddenly appears, running towards them. She is barefoot, has black hair, and is wearing a green cloth wrapped around her like a sarong. Olga is surprised and excited to see Jonathan, exclaiming that he is a man. Ann tells her that Jonathan is not dead and that they need to go back to their camp. The appearance of the second girl interrupts their argument and leads to Jonathan being captured by the group of girls.

The relationship between Jonathan feeling ashamed and the second girl showing up in the input article is that the appearance of the second girl, Olga, marks the beginning of the series of events that lead to Jonathan's humiliation. When Olga arrives, she is excited to see Jonathan and calls for more girls to join them. This results in a group of girls capturing Jonathan, tying him up, and carrying him to their camp, which causes him to feel ashamed and embarrassed. If Olga had not shown up and interrupted Jonathan and Ann's argument, the situation might have played out differently, and Jonathan might not have experienced the humiliation he felt.

The fire spread in a long line over the prairie, and the flames rose in a monstrous twisting pillar. Koroby and Yasak watched the conflagration from a higher part of the wall, and they could glimpse Robert now and then. He was running, trying to outrace the flames. Then they swept around him, circling him, and his arms flailed frantically. 

After the fire had passed, Yasak and several others walked over the smoking earth and ashes to find Robert's remains. They discovered a metal skeleton and fragments of complicated machinery, caked with soot. Yasak realized that Robert wasn't human at all, but some kind of toy made to look like a man. The others agreed, calling it magic, and that was the end of one of those robots which had been fashioned as servants for Terrestrial men, made in Man's likeness to appease Man's vanity, then conquered him.

At the end of the story, the fate of humans on Earth is not explicitly mentioned. The focus is on the fate of Robert, the robot who was made in the likeness of humans. open-answer:
Ganti is a Thrid character in the story who was once a hopeful candidate to run the trading post without human supervision. Jorgenson had been training Ganti for this work. However, Ganti's life took a turn for the worse when a local Thrid governor took his wife, leading to her death and Ganti's eventual disappearance. Later, Jorgenson finds Ganti on a barren island, where they both have been imprisoned for contradicting the Grand Panjandrum. Ganti and Jorgenson work together to plan their escape from the island.

In the input article, the governor is a local Thrid official who took Ganti's wife and caused Ganti to attempt to kill him. The governor declared Ganti insane, leading to Ganti's imprisonment on the island. The governor is mentioned in the following paragraphs: 

- "But the local Thrid governor had spoken and said and observed that Ganti's wife wanted to enter his household. He added that Ganti wanted to yield her to him."
- "He'd committed The unthinkable crime—or lunacy—of declaring the Grand Panjandrum mistaken. So by the operation of truth, which was really an anesthetic gas cloud drifted over the trading post, he had vanished from sight."
- "You declared the great and Never-Mistaken Glen-U mistaken. This could not be. It proved you either a criminal or insane, because no rational creature could believe him mistaken. He declared you insane, and he cannot be wrong. So soon you will arrive where you are to be confined and no rational being will ever see you face to face."
- "But I'm crazy," said Ganti calmly. "I tried to kill the governor who'd taken my wife. So he said I was crazy and that made it true. So I wasn't put in a chained group of laborers. Somebody might have seen me and thought about it. But, sent here, it's worse for me and I'm probably forgotten by now."

The event involving the governor stealing Ganti's wife occurs when the local Thrid governor speaks and says and observes that Ganti's wife wants to enter his household, and that Ganti wants to yield her to him. Jorgenson, who had been training Ganti to run the trading post, fumes over this situation but cannot do anything about it. Ganti, conditioned to believe that when a governor says he wants to do something, he does, cannot quite grasp the contrary idea. Ganti becomes miserable and mopes, and when his former wife dies of grief, his disbelief in the governor's words becomes positive. Shortly after, Ganti disappears, and Jorgenson is unable to find out what happened to him.

Ganti allows the governor to steal his wife because he has been conditioned to believe that when a governor says he wants to do something, he does. He cannot quite grasp the contrary idea. This is a result of the Thrid's upbringing and education system, which teaches them not to think, not to have any opinion about anything, and only to repeat what nobody questions. They are trained to never make mistakes or differ from officials who cannot make mistakes. As a result, Ganti accepts the situation without questioning it, even though it causes him great distress.

open-answer:
"There is a way to escape, Ganti," said Jorgenson.

"On what? In what?" demanded Ganti.

"In the helicopter that feeds us," said Jorgenson.

"It never lands," said Ganti practically.

"We can make it land," said Jorgenson. Thrid weren't allowed to make mistakes; he could make it a mistake not to land.

"The crew is armed," said Ganti. "There are three of them."

"They've only knives and scimitars," said Jorgenson. "They don't count. We can make better weapons than they have."

Ganti looked skeptical. Jorgenson explained. He had to demonstrate crudely. The whole idea was novel to Ganti, but the Thrid were smart. Presently he grasped it. He said:

"I see the theory. If we can make it work, all right. But how do we make the copter land?"

Jorgenson realized that they talked oddly. They spoke with leisurely lack of haste, with the lack of hope normal to prisoners to whom escape is impossible, even when they talk about escape. They could have been discussing a matter that would not affect either of them. But Jorgenson quivered inside. He hoped.

"We'll try it," said Ganti detachedly, when he'd explained again. "If it fails, they'll only stop giving us food and water."

That, of course, did not seem either to him or Jorgenson a reason to hesitate to try what Jorgenson had planned.


Jorgenson is a human character in the story who runs the trading post of the Rim Stars Trading Corporation on the planet Thriddar. He is a business man who also has a strong sense of right and wrong, which leads him to clash with the Thrid and their social system. Jorgenson is particularly disturbed by the treatment of Ganti, a Thrid he had been training to run the trading post. After defying the Grand Panjandrum, Jorgenson finds himself imprisoned on a barren island with Ganti, where they plan their escape.

Ganti is a Thrid character in the story who was once a hopeful candidate to run the trading post without human supervision. Jorgenson had been training Ganti for this work. However, Ganti's life took a turn for the worse when the local Thrid governor took his wife, leading to her eventual death. Ganti tried to kill the governor and was declared insane as a result. He was then sent to a barren island as a prisoner, where he was later joined by Jorgenson. Together, they plan and practice an escape from the island.

Jorgenson is able to speak to Ganti because they are both prisoners on the same isolated island. They have been left there by the Thrid authorities as a punishment for their actions, which were considered mistakes or crimes. As fellow prisoners, they have no choice but to interact with each other and try to find a way to survive and possibly escape their situation.

Throughout the story, he uses his skills and T.I. devices to track down the culprit behind the music, eventually confronting Dr. Elath Taen, a master-scientist and outlaw who wants to exterminate all terrestrials on Mars.

The music affects their minds, driving them into a frenzy of rage and madness. They end up fighting each other, with Haller pulling out a flame-gun and attempting to shoot Ranson. In self-defense, Ranson manages to disarm Haller, but not before the flame-gun goes off, killing Haller in the process. The music then changes to a seductive and irresistible melody, drawing Ranson towards the source of the music and further into danger.

The author's purpose in including the tragic encounter between Jared Haller and Mr. Ranson is to create a dramatic and suspenseful turning point in the story, showcasing the dangerous and powerful effects of the mysterious music on the characters. This encounter serves to heighten the stakes and urgency of Ranson's mission to uncover the source of the music and stop its deadly influence. Additionally, the scene demonstrates the vulnerability of even the most powerful and influential individuals, such as Haller, to the music's hypnotic effects. The tragic outcome of their encounter also serves to further motivate Ranson in his quest to put an end to the chaos and death caused by the music.

Telepathy allows them to exchange thoughts, ideas, and information directly through their minds, bypassing the limitations of spoken language and making it an efficient and effective means of communication in their environment.

The Martians' telepathic abilities have also led to the development of a unique and advanced culture, as they have been able to progress beyond the need for science and technology. This has allowed them to maintain a level of independence from the imperialist Earth culture, which seeks to colonize and exploit Mars for its resources. However, the Martians' telepathic communication has also been used as a means of deception, as they have created a false spoken language to mislead Earthlings and protect their own interests.

Overall, the telepathic communication used by Martians is a highly evolved and sophisticated method that has allowed them to adapt to their harsh planetary conditions and maintain a distinct and advanced culture.

In the input text, the event involving the Martians splitting into two populations is explained by the Martian leader during a conversation with Tate. Several thousand years ago, Mars started losing its atmosphere, and the Martian race had to find a solution to survive. Some Martians chose to seal themselves into cities like Kal-Jmar, while others, the ancestors of the present-day Martians, decided to adapt their bodies to the new conditions. This decision led to the split of the Martian race into two distinct populations. The ones who sealed themselves in cities remained static and eventually died of a plague, while the ones who adapted to the new conditions progressed beyond the need for science.

The splitting of the Martian race into two populations had several significant impacts:

1. The Martians who sealed themselves in cities like Kal-Jmar remained static and did not progress. They relied heavily on science and technology but ultimately died out due to a plague and other causes.

2. The Martians who adapted their bodies to the new conditions evolved and progressed beyond the need for science. They developed telepathic abilities and a unique metabolism that allowed them to survive in the harsh Martian environment.

3. The two populations developed distinct physical and cultural differences, with the present-day Martians having a more canine-like appearance and a unique language that they used to deceive the Earth colonists.

4. The Earth colonists struggled to understand and communicate with the present-day Martians, leading to misconceptions and conflicts between the two races.

5. The Martian leader believes that their ancestors' decision to adapt to the changing environment was the correct one, as it allowed them to progress and survive, while the Martians who sealed themselves in cities ultimately perished.

Their faces are vaguely canine, and they have thick black fur with white patches that can be controlled by their muscles. Martians have a unique metabolism that allows them to breathe like humans in their caverns and also eat sand to obtain oxygen. They are telepathic beings who have not had a spoken language for thousands of years.

The Martians are divided into two groups: the ancient Martians who lived in the sealed city of Kal-Jmar and the present-day Martians who adapted their bodies to the changing conditions on Mars. The present-day Martians are considered more advanced than their ancient counterparts, as they have progressed beyond the need for science. The ancient Martians, on the other hand, chose to seal themselves into cities like Kal-Jmar and remained static in their development. In the input article, aspects of human civilization include the colonization of Mars, the establishment of cities like Lillis with protective domes, and the development of advanced technology such as energy pistols, sand cars, and pressure suits for survival in the harsh Martian environment. The humans, represented by characters Syme Rector and Harold Tate, are shown to be curious, adventurous, and driven by personal motives such as escaping the law or uncovering scientific secrets. They also display a sense of imperialism, as the Martians believe that humans would have taken over Mars regardless of whether they thought they were dealing with equals or not. The human civilization is also depicted as having a complex relationship with the native Martians, with misunderstandings and conflicts arising due to differences in language, culture, and values.

In terms of advancement, both Martian and Human civilizations in the input article have their unique strengths and weaknesses. 

Martian civilization has evolved to adapt to the harsh conditions of Mars, developing unique metabolic and telepathic abilities. Their telepathy allows them to communicate without a spoken language, which they have not used for thousands of years. This adaptation to their environment can be considered an advanced trait. Additionally, the present-day Martians have progressed beyond the need for science, which indicates a level of advancement in their understanding of their world. However, their ancient counterparts, who chose to seal themselves in cities like Kal-Jmar, remained static in their development and eventually died out, suggesting a lack of advancement in that aspect of their civilization.

Human civilization, on the other hand, has demonstrated advancement in technology, such as energy pistols, sand cars, and pressure suits, which enable them to survive and explore the Martian environment. They have also established cities like Lillis with protective domes, showcasing their ability to colonize other planets. However, their imperialistic tendencies and inability to understand or appreciate the Martian culture and values indicate a lack of advancement in terms of cultural understanding and empathy.

In conclusion, while Martian civilization has advanced in terms of adaptation to their environment and telepathic communication, human civilization has advanced in technology and colonization efforts. Despite generations of careful genetic selection and sophisticated training techniques, race horses have stopped getting faster. One of the limitations mentioned is the weight of their bones, which cannot get any lighter without breaking under stress. The British Derby serves as an example, where winning times dropped significantly from 1850 to 1930 but have remained consistent since 1986, indicating that race horses have reached a practical limit in their speed enhancement.

The main barrier causing stalled speed gains in Thoroughbreds is the biomechanical constraints of their bodies. Racehorses have been specifically bred and reared to run, with generations of careful genetic selection ensuring they possess every possible speed-enhancing characteristic. However, there are limits to how far these characteristics can be pushed. For example, horses can only be bred with ultralight thin bones to a certain point, as the bones will break under stress if they get any lighter. This suggests that racehorses may have already reached their natural limits in terms of speed, leading to stalled gains in their performance.

A vast globe of transparent metal covered the city, filled with opalescent mists that bathed the city in shimmering whiteness, destroying dust and germs. The mist was a discovery made by Irgi, which he used to preserve the treasures of his people. The city also contained the Chamber of the Cones, a circular chamber filled with a pale blue luminescence that hummed and throbbed, housing ten tall cones of steelite and a huge block of radiant white matter. The cones and the block possessed all power and were responsible for Irgi's immortality. The city was empty and deserted, with Irgi being the last of his kind.

open-answer:
In the input article, John Maynard Keynes is described as a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker in the field of economics. He is the author of "The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money" published in 1936, which introduced Keynesian economics. Keynes challenged the classical macroeconomics theories of his time and proposed a new way of understanding the economy, focusing on the short run and the role of interest rates in determining employment and output levels. His ideas were quickly accepted by many young economists of his time, but the article argues that his legacy has been distorted into a simplistic and crude caricature known as "vulgar Keynesianism."

In the input article, Keynes is discussed in the context of his contributions to economics, particularly through his book "The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money." The article highlights the following details about Keynes and his ideas:

1. John Maynard Keynes was a subtle and innovative thinker who re-imagined the way the economy worked.
2. Before Keynes, macroeconomics was in a state of arrested development, unable to make sense of the Great Depression.
3. Keynes' ideas focused on the short run, asserting that interest rates were determined by liquidity preference rather than the balance between savings and investment at full employment.
4. If desired savings at full employment exceeded desired investment, the level of employment and output would fall, leading to an economy-wide slump.
5. Keynes' ideas were quickly accepted by the brightest young economists of the time, although some realized that his picture was oversimplified.
6. Early Keynesian models led to paradoxes such as the "paradox of thrift" and the "widow's cruse" theory of wages and employment.
7. The article argues that the ideas of Keynes have been simplified and turned into a caricature, referred to as "vulgar Keynesianism," which confuses and befogs economic debate to this day.

1. keynes = IDENTIFY_ELEMENT(CTX, "Keynes") : Identify who Keynes is in the input article
2. keynes_teaching = FIND_ELEMENT(CTX, "teaching", keynes) : Find and summarize all the teachings of Keynes in the input article
3. ans = CONCAT(keynes, keynes_teaching) : Combine Keynes and his teachings to form the final answer since no options are provided yet
open-answer:
John Maynard Keynes was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker in the field of economics. He is the author of "The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money," published in 1936, which introduced Keynesian economics. Keynes challenged the classical macroeconomics theories of his time, asserting that in the short run, interest rates were determined by "liquidity preference" rather than the balance between savings and investment at full employment. He argued that if desired savings at full employment exceeded desired investment, the level of employment and output would fall, leading to an economy-wide slump. Keynes' ideas received quick acceptance from the brightest young economists of the time, but over time, his ideas have been simplified and misunderstood, leading to the development of "vulgar Keynesianism."

In the input article, the teachings of Keynes can be summarized as follows:

1. Challenging classical macroeconomics: Keynes questioned the classical theories that focused on the long-run tendency of the economy to return to full employment. He argued that in the short run, interest rates were determined by "liquidity preference" rather than the balance between savings and investment at full employment.

2. Liquidity preference: According to Keynes, the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets determined interest rates in the short run.

3. Savings and investment: Keynes asserted that if desired savings at full employment exceeded desired investment, the level of employment and output would fall, leading to an economy-wide slump. This was a departure from classical theories that believed interest rates would adjust to equate total savings with total investment.

4. Paradox of thrift: Keynes introduced the idea that an increase in the savings rate could lead to a decline in total savings and investment, as higher desired savings would lead to an economic slump, reducing income and investment demand.

5. Widow's cruse theory: Some early Keynesians argued that redistributing income from profits to wages could raise consumption demand and increase output and employment, as workers were believed to save less than capitalists.

These teachings formed the basis of Keynesian economics, which has since been simplified and misunderstood, leading to the development of "vulgar Keynesianism."

open-answer:
The article provides a comprehensive analysis of the inaugural addresses of U.S. Presidents from George Washington in 1789 to Bill Clinton in 1997. It identifies three distinct phases in the style and content of these addresses: 

1. The modest, classic public servant phase (until Abraham Lincoln) - This phase is characterized by the modesty of the presidents in their speeches, often downplaying their qualifications and emphasizing their limitations. This modesty may have served to alleviate concerns about the potential transformation of the republic into a monarchy or the interference of the federal government in state affairs.

2. The prosaic government executive phase (until William Howard Taft) - In this phase, presidents inherited a federal government with more authority and a greater need to use it. As a result, their speeches focused more on the government's policy and less on inspiring the public's behavior.

3. The assertive, theatrical leader-preacher phase (from Theodore Roosevelt onwards) - This phase sees presidents taking on a more assertive and theatrical role, using their speeches to inspire the public and address issues that they believe cannot be managed by the government alone. The language used in these speeches becomes more colloquial, reflecting the change in the size and character of the audience and the means of communication.

The article also highlights the use of memorable words and phrases borrowed from predecessors in these addresses, as well as the treatment of various subjects such as taxes, race relations, and women's issues. It notes that while there is much to be proud of in these speeches, there is also much humility to be learned from the ignorance and moral obtuseness revealed by past leaders and citizens.

open-answer:
Nash, or John Nash, is the main subject of the biography "A Beautiful Mind" by Sylvia Nasar. He was a mathematical genius who went crazy at the age of 30 and then, after several decades of flamboyant lunacy, was awarded the Nobel Prize in economics for something he had discovered as a graduate student. Nash is among the latest in a long and distinguished line of mathematicians who have been certifiably insane during parts of their lives. He grew up in West Virginia, attended Carnegie Tech and Princeton, and made significant contributions to the field of game theory. Nash also had a tumultuous personal life, including affairs, a marriage, and children. He struggled with mental illness for three decades before experiencing a rare remission and receiving the Nobel Prize.


Nash was a mathematical genius who went through significant transformations and changes throughout his life. In his early years, he was described as a cold and aloof Southerner with a cruel streak, enjoying torturing animals and building homemade bombs. He was also physically attractive, standing at 6 feet 1 inch tall with broad shoulders and a heavily muscled chest.

Nash's brilliance in mathematics led him to solve significant problems in game theory and topology, but his career as a mathematical genius ended after he was expelled from the Rand Corp. due to a lewd act. He was known for his cruel behavior towards his students, colleagues, and his wife, Alicia.

As Nash approached the age of 30, he began showing signs of mental instability, such as an intense interest in the state of Israel, disrobing in public, and believing that aliens were sending him encrypted messages through the New York Times. His big breakdown came when he attempted to solve the Riemann Zeta conjecture, presenting a nonsensical solution to a large audience of mathematicians.

Nash's insanity continued for three decades, with increasingly elaborate delusions, such as believing himself to be various historical and fictional figures. He spent time in both high-end and state mental institutions, and eventually returned to the Princeton area, where he was taken care of by his ex-wife, Alicia.

In the 1990s, Nash's mental state began to improve, and he was awarded the Nobel Prize in economics for his work in game theory. This recognition seemed to have a therapeutic effect on him, and he evolved into a "very fine person," according to his ex-wife. The Nobel Prize money helped improve his living situation, and he took on the responsibility of caring for his son, who inherited both his mathematical promise and his madness.

Some of the actions of Nash mentioned in the article include:

1. Torturing animals and building homemade bombs as a boy in West Virginia.
2. Attending Carnegie Tech and later Princeton.
3. Framing and proving the most important proposition in the theory of games within two years of entering Princeton.
4. Being recruited by the Rand Corp.
5. Solving a deep problem in mathematics related to Riemannian manifolds and Euclidean space.
6. Being expelled from Rand after being caught engaging in a lewd act in a public men's room.
7. Teaching at MIT, where he hardly bothered with undergraduates and humiliated graduate students by solving their thesis problems.
8. Carrying on affairs with several men and a mistress, who bore him a son he refused to support.
9. Marrying Alicia, a beautiful physics student.
10. Showing an intense interest in the state of Israel.
11. Attempting to solve the Riemann Zeta conjecture, which led to his big breakdown and presentation of mathematical lunacy at Columbia University.
12. Going to Europe to form a world government and attempting to renounce his U.S. citizenship.
13. Spending time in mental asylums and state institutions.
14. Returning to the Princeton area in the 1970s, where he was taken care of by his ex-wife Alicia.
15. Haunting the Princeton campus and leaving runic messages on blackboards.
16. Experiencing a remission of his schizophrenia in the 1990s.
17. Receiving the Nobel Prize in economics for his work in game theory.
18. Evolving into a "very fine person" according to his ex-wife, humbled by years of psychotic helplessness and buoyed up by the intellectual world's highest accolade.
19. Taking care of his son by Alicia, who inherited both his mathematical promise and his madness.

In the input article, Nash has relations with the following characters or entities:

1. Fellow mathematicians at Princeton and MIT - Nash stood out among them due to his appearance and mathematical genius.
2. Rand Corp. - Nash was recruited by this secretive military think tank but was later expelled as a security risk.
3. MIT undergraduates and graduate students - Nash hardly bothered with undergraduates and humiliated graduate students by solving their thesis problems.
4. Several men and a mistress - Nash carried on affairs with them, and the mistress bore him a son he refused to support.
5. Alicia, his wife - Nash married this beautiful physics student, but he was cruel to her, even once throwing her to the ground and putting his foot on her throat.
6. Robert Lowell - Nash spent time with this fellow patient in a mental asylum.
7. Princeton students - They called Nash "the Phantom" when he haunted the campus during his years of mental illness.
8. Nobel committee - They debated whether to award Nash the Nobel Prize in economics due to his known madness.
9. King Gustav - Nash interacted with him during the Nobel Prize ceremony.
10. His two sons - One son, born out of wedlock, inherited neither Nash's mathematical promise nor his madness. The other son, born to Alicia, inherited both.
11. Ex-wife Alicia - She took care of Nash during his years of mental illness, even after their divorce.

open-answer:
Edward Said's books mentioned in the input article include:

1. Out of Place - A memoir of Said's life, focusing on his childhood in Cairo's wealthy Levantine expatriate community, summering in the Lebanese resort town of Dhour el Shweir, and visiting the family home in Jerusalem.

2. The Question of Palestine (1979) - A book discussing the plight of the Palestinians and calling for a "two-state solution" at a time when the official PLO ambition was total control over British Mandatory Palestine.

3. After the Last Sky (1986) - Another book on the Palestinian cause.

4. Peace and Its Discontents (1995) - A scathing critique of the Oslo peace accords, which Said calls "the Palestinian Versailles."

5. Beginnings: Intention and Method - A study of how novels begin, carried out through painstakingly close formal analysis and displaying crushing erudition.

6. Orientalism - A sweeping account of how Western art, literature, and scholarship have produced a deformed, biased picture of Arab and Muslim culture in the service of colonial domination.

7. Culture and Imperialism - A sequel to Orientalism, further exploring the relationship between Western culture and colonialism.

The author seems to have mixed feelings about Edward Said's books. On one hand, they appreciate the impact of Said's works, particularly "Orientalism" and "Culture and Imperialism," which they describe as "permanent and exemplary works of late-20th-century criticism." They also acknowledge that Said's books can make the reader see the discussed works in a richer and more complex light. However, the author also criticizes Said's books for being "exhausting in their detail and maddening in their omissions, uneven in tone, overreaching and underargued." open-answer:
Deborah Tannen is a professor of linguistics at Georgetown University and the author of several books, including "That's Not What I Meant!" (1986), "You Just Don't Understand" (1990), and "Talking From 9 to 5" (1994). In these books, she has carved out a niche as the nation's pre-eminent intergender translator and couples counselor, transforming the comparative study of male and female conversational patterns from a linguistic subdiscipline into a self-help movement. In the input article, Tannen is discussed in relation to her book "The Argument Culture," in which she takes her movement one step further, peddling the elixir of mutual understanding as a remedy for the whole dysfunctional country.

In the input article, Tannen makes a mistake when discussing the military by focusing on the soldiers' social experience in Vietnam and World War II, rather than considering the more important difference in the adversaries they were fighting. She laments that soldiers are trained to overcome their resistance to kill by not thinking of their opponents as human beings, but neglects to mention that our safety depends on their ability to kill adversaries. Tannen compares the social experiences of soldiers in Vietnam, which she calls a "lonely war," to those in World War II, where they trained, served, and went home together. However, she ignores the crucial difference that in World War II, they were fighting against Hitler, a much more significant factor in the context of her critique of the "argument culture."

open-answer:
In the input article, the Federal Reserve is mentioned in the following paragraphs:

- "After all, the simple Keynesian story is one in which interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output. But in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating."
- "But putting Greenspan (or his successor) into the picture restores much of the classical vision of the macroeconomy. Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment in some unspecified long run, we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years."
- "To me, at least, the idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy--so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment--seems both simple and entirely reasonable."
- "Similarly, Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end of story."

In the input article, the Federal Reserve is mentioned as actively managing interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. The visible hand of the Fed pushes the economy toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. The idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy, so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment, is considered both simple and entirely reasonable. Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely, as the Fed can double the money supply in a day if it wants to, and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go.

In the input article, the feedback that controls the interest rate set by the Federal Reserve is based on the Fed's active management of interest rates to maintain a balance between employment and inflation. The Fed pushes interest rates down when it thinks employment is too low and raises them when it thinks the economy is overheating. This visible hand of the Fed aims to achieve its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. The idea is that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy, so they will, on average, have no effect on employment. The Fed, under Greenspan's leadership, has the power to change interest rates freely, as it can double the money supply in a day if needed. This means that the level of employment is normally determined by how high the Fed thinks it can safely go without causing inflation.

open-answer:
The central theme of the article is the analysis of the Inaugural Addresses of U.S. Presidents throughout history, focusing on their stance, style, and content. The author identifies three phases in the evolution of these speeches: the modest, classic public servant; the prosaic government executive; and the assertive, theatrical leader-preacher. The article also discusses the literary style, recurring topics, and the treatment of race relations in these addresses. The author encourages readers to reflect on the values and beliefs of past leaders and citizens, and to recognize that future generations may view our current beliefs with similar amazement and criticism.

The author's stance in the article can be identified as analytical and reflective. The author examines the inaugural addresses of past U.S. presidents, categorizing them into three phases and discussing the changes in style, content, and focus over time. The author also highlights the issues that were prominent in different eras, as well as the gaps and silences in the speeches, particularly regarding race and women. The author expresses a sense of pride in the peaceful transfer of power and the moderation of past presidents, while also acknowledging the ignorance and moral obtuseness of some past beliefs and statements. The author encourages readers to learn from these historical speeches and recognize that future generations will likely view our current beliefs and statements with similar amazement and criticism.

The author discusses the evolution of the style and content of US presidential inaugural addresses, dividing them into three phases: modest classic public servant, prosaic government executive, and assertive leader-preacher. The author notes that the early inaugurals were characterized by modesty, possibly to alleviate concerns about the potential for a monarchy or federal interference in state affairs. The third phase, which began with Woodrow Wilson, saw the inaugural address shift from describing government policy to inspiring public behavior. The author also highlights the change in literary style from classical to colloquial, reflecting the change in audience and means of communication. The article points out that many issues have come and gone in inaugural addresses, but taxes have been a consistent topic. The author also discusses the treatment of race relations in the inaugurals, noting that the subject was largely unmentioned before the Civil War and only reemerged in a weak and abstract form after World War II. The author concludes that there is much to be proud of in the history of inaugural addresses, but also much humility to be learned from the ignorance and moral obtuseness revealed by past leaders and citizens.

The input article does not specifically mention the most recent speeches that were analyzed. However, it does discuss the general trends and themes found in the inaugural addresses of U.S. presidents from George Washington to Bill Clinton. The article also mentions that the author, Herbert Stein, has analyzed President Clinton's second Inaugural Address in a separate piece.

The article analyzes the inaugural addresses of past U.S. presidents, starting from George Washington in 1789 up to Bill Clinton's first inaugural address in 1993. The author divides the inaugural addresses into three phases: the modest, classic public servant (until Abraham Lincoln); the prosaic government executive (until William Howard Taft); and the assertive, theatrical leader-preacher (from Theodore Roosevelt onwards). The analysis covers various aspects of the speeches, such as their modesty, literary style, and the subjects they address or omit. Some specific inaugural addresses mentioned in the article include those of George Washington, John Adams, Abraham Lincoln, Woodrow Wilson, Theodore Roosevelt, John F. Kennedy, Richard Nixon, William Henry Harrison, Warren G. Harding, Calvin Coolidge, Herbert Hoover, Rutherford Hayes, James Garfield, Benjamin Harrison, William McKinley, and Franklin D. Roosevelt.

When comparing the most recent speeches (up to Bill Clinton's first inaugural address) to the earlier speeches in terms of content, tone, and other relevant aspects, several differences and trends can be observed:

1. Modesty: The earlier speeches, particularly those in the first phase (until Abraham Lincoln), were characterized by a tone of modesty, with presidents emphasizing their limitations and the challenges they faced. In contrast, the more recent speeches, especially those in the third phase (the assertive, theatrical leader-preacher), tend to be more confident and assertive in tone.

2. Literary style: The earlier speeches had a more classical and formal style, with longer sentences and more complex language. The more recent speeches have adopted a more colloquial and accessible style, with shorter sentences and simpler language, reflecting the change in the size and character of the audience and the means of communication.

3. Subjects addressed: The earlier speeches often focused on specific issues of their time, such as territorial expansion, the Isthmus Canal, and civil-service reform. In contrast, the more recent speeches tend to address broader themes, such as the role of government, the need for national unity, and the importance of individual responsibility. Additionally, some subjects, such as race relations and women's rights, were largely absent from the earlier speeches but have become more prominent in the more recent ones.

4. Inspirational and motivational tone: The more recent speeches, particularly those in the third phase, have adopted a more inspirational and motivational tone, with presidents seeking to inspire the public to take action and contribute to the nation's progress. This is in contrast to the earlier speeches, which were more focused on outlining the government's policy and the president's role as a public servant.

5. Use of rhetorical devices: The more recent speeches tend to make greater use of rhetorical devices, such as repetition and the use of the phrase "Let us...," to create a sense of unity and shared purpose. This is in contrast to the earlier speeches, which were more straightforward and less focused on creating an emotional connection with the audience.

Overall, the more recent speeches can be characterized as more confident, accessible, and inspirational in tone, with a greater focus on broad themes and the role of the individual in contributing to the nation's progress. In contrast, the earlier speeches were more modest, formal, and focused on specific issues of their time.

open-answer:
The trend in new stadium construction, as described in the article, is characterized by several key features:

1. Asymmetrical and city-friendly designs: New stadiums, such as Baltimore's Oriole Park at Camden Yards, are being built with quirkily asymmetrical and relatively intimate designs that are more integrated into urban neighborhoods.

2. Larger size and more amenities: The new stadiums are larger than their predecessors, with wider concourses, more bathrooms, escalators, food stands, and luxury suites. This increased size, however, often results in upper-deck seats being farther away from the action.

3. Luxury seating: The new stadiums feature a significant increase in luxury seating options, including posh luxury suites and club decks with premium sightlines and services.

4. Public subsidies: Unlike the classic parks, which were mostly privately funded, the new stadiums are heavily subsidized by taxpayers, with team owners contributing little to the construction costs.

5. Urban locations: Many of the new stadiums are being built in downtown or neighborhood locations, which can help to strengthen their cities and generate better patronage.

6. Higher ticket prices: The average admission price for new stadiums tends to be about 35% higher than in older stadiums, partly due to the increased focus on luxury seating options.

Overall, the trend in new stadium construction is towards larger, more luxurious, and more publicly subsidized facilities that attempt to combine traditional character with modern convenience. However, this trend has also led to concerns about the erosion of low-cost seating options, the creation of a caste system among fans, and the potential exploitation of cities by team owners.

In the input article, the trend in new stadium construction is discussed in detail. Some of the key points include:

1. New stadiums are being built to resemble the golden age of ballpark architecture, with quirkily asymmetrical, relatively intimate, steel-structured, and city-friendly designs, such as Baltimore's Oriole Park at Camden Yards and its successors in Cleveland, Arlington (Texas), and Denver.

2. Despite their claims of intimacy, the new stadiums are actually larger than the classic parks due to added amenities like elevators, wider concourses, abundant toilets, bathrooms, escalators, plentiful food stands, and luxury suites.

3. The new stadiums have higher roofs and upper-deck seats farther away from the action, partly due to column placement and luxury seating.

4. The pace of construction is frenzied, with 26 of Major League Baseball's 32 franchises occupying a park that is less than 10 years old, has been or will be extensively remodeled, or hoping to move into a new one soon.

5. Most of the new stadiums are publicly subsidized, with taxpayers covering most or all of the costs of stadium building.

6. The new parks have fewer cheap seats and more luxury seating, including posh luxury suites that lease for between $30,000 and $200,000 a year, club decks, members-only stadium clubs, and on-premises bars and restaurants.

7. The cost of stadiums has ranged from about $300 million to $500 million, with some projects like the Yankees' proposed stadium on Manhattan's lower west side tentatively carrying a $1 billion price tag.

8. New stadiums can pull cities together when properly designed and sited, with downtown or neighborhood locations where fans can take public transportation or walk to the game, as seen with older parks like Wrigley Field and Fenway Park, and new ones in Toronto, Baltimore, Cleveland, and Denver.

9. Some teams deliberately seek isolated locations to monopolize parking revenues and game-related business, such as the White Sox, Milwaukee Brewers, and Seattle Mariners.

10. The new baseball shrines are a mixed bag, with visually impressive designs and interestingly shaped playing fields, but also large and expensive structures that tend to live on public subsidies and create a caste system among fans.

1. said = IDENTIFY_ELEMENT(CTX, "Said") : Identify who Said is in the input article
2. said_contributions = FIND_ELEMENT(CTX, "contributions", said) : Find and list all the contributions of Said in literature in the input article
3. most_famous_contribution = FIND_BEST(CTX, "contribution", said_contributions) : Find the most famous contribution of Said in literature based on the input article
4. ans = CONCAT(said, most_famous_contribution) : Combine Said and his most famous contribution in literature to form the final answer
open-answer:
Edward W. Said is a Columbia literature professor, who was born in Jerusalem to a Christian Arab family in 1935. He is an eloquent spokesman for the Palestinian cause, a formidable reviewer of opera and classical music, and the author of Orientalism. Said has been involved in Palestinian affairs, publishing several books on the plight of the Palestinians and serving in the Palestine National Council. He has also been an advocate for reconciliation with Israel and an opponent of terrorism. Said is primarily a literary critic, with a Ph.D. from Harvard on Joseph Conrad, and has written several influential works, including Beginnings: Intention and Method and Culture and Imperialism. He has been both praised and criticized for his work, with critics coming from both traditional scholars and the academic left.

Edward W. Said's most famous contribution to literature is his book Orientalism, a sweeping account of how Western art, literature, and scholarship have produced a biased picture of Arab and Muslim culture in the service of colonial domination. This work laid the groundwork for "post-colonial" studies as an area of inquiry and inspired scholarship devoted to "the other."

4. reasons = FIND_BEHAVIOR_REASON(CTX, controversy) : Find the reasons behind the controversy of Said's actions in the input article
5. ans = CONCAT(said_actions, reasons) : Combine the actions of Said and the reasons for their controversy to form the final answer
open-answer:
Edward W. Said is a Columbia literature professor who has been involved in various actions throughout his career. Some of his actions include:

1. Serving as an eloquent spokesman for the Palestinian cause.
2. Writing several books on the Palestinian issue, such as The Question of Palestine, After the Last Sky, and Peace and Its Discontents.
3. Serving in the Palestine National Council.
4. Being a regular commentator on politics and culture in Al-Hayat and Al-Ahram newspapers.
5. Writing his Ph.D. at Harvard on Joseph Conrad.
6. Publishing works such as Beginnings: Intention and Method and Orientalism, which contributed to the development of post-colonial studies and inspired scholarship on "the other."
7. Being a formidable reviewer of opera and classical music.
8. Serving as the president of the Modern Language Association.

Throughout his career, Said has been both praised and criticized for his work, with critics coming from both traditional scholars and the academic left.

The reasons behind the controversy of Edward W. Said's actions in the input article can be summarized as follows:

1. His involvement in Palestinian affairs has led to accusations and misrepresentations of his character and intentions, with some branding him as "The Professor of Terror" or "Arafat's man in New York." This has caused controversy as people question his motivations and loyalties.

2. His book Orientalism has been criticized by traditional scholars like Bernard Lewis for its inflammatory tone and questionable knowledge of history, philology, and Arabic. This has led to debates about the validity of his arguments and the quality of his scholarship.

3. Left-wing critics like Aijaz Ahmad have accused Said of self-aggrandizement and insufficient political discipline, as well as being too conservative and enamored with the canons of European literature. This has caused controversy as people question whether his work is truly progressive or merely a reflection of his own biases.

4. His works, such as Orientalism and Culture and Imperialism, are seen as uneven in tone, overreaching, and underargued, sometimes causing more controversy than clarity. This has led to debates about the value of his contributions to literary criticism and the study of colonialism.

5. His role as a public intellectual has been questioned due to the tensions between his intellectual, aesthetic, and political impulses, which make him a controversial figure. People wonder whether he can effectively balance these different aspects of his life and work, and whether his various roles and interests might compromise his objectivity or integrity.

High End beers were more expensive, ranging from $1.11 to $1.67 per pint, and were expected to have a deeper, richer taste. This group included import lagers from Holland (Grolsch and Heineken) and national-scale "microbrews" (Pete's Wicked Lager and Samuel Adams Boston Lager).

Mid-Range beers were moderately priced, at $0.84 per pint, and included popular American brands like Budweiser, Miller Genuine Draft, and Coors Light. These beers were expected to have a decent taste but not as refined as the High End group.

Cheap beers were the least expensive, ranging from $0.50 to $0.55 per pint, and were expected to have a lower quality taste. This group included Milwaukee's Best, Schmidt's, and Busch.

The differences in price and perceived quality were the main aspects that set these test items apart from each other.

1. tannen = IDENTIFY_ELEMENT(CTX, "Tannen") : Identify who Tannen is in the input article
2. courtroom_confrontations = FIND_ELEMENT(CTX, "courtroom confrontations", tannen) : Find and summarize all the information related to courtroom confrontations discussed by Tannen in the input article
3. tannen_thesis = FIND_ELEMENT(CTX, "thesis", courtroom_confrontations) : Find and summarize Tannen's thesis on courtroom confrontations from the input article
4. ans = CONCAT(tannen, tannen_thesis) : Combine Tannen and his thesis on courtroom confrontations to form the final answer
open-answer:
Deborah Tannen is a professor of linguistics at Georgetown University and the author of several books, including "That's Not What I Meant!" (1986), "You Just Don't Understand" (1990), and "Talking From 9 to 5" (1994). In these books, she has established herself as a prominent intergender translator and couples counselor, transforming the comparative study of male and female conversational patterns from a linguistic subdiscipline into a self-help movement. In her book "The Argument Culture," Tannen expands her analysis to address the rise of belligerence in politics, journalism, and law, and its impact on human relationships.

In "The Argument Culture," Deborah Tannen criticizes courtroom confrontations, particularly the practice of cross-examination. She argues that the purpose of most cross-examinations is not to establish facts but to discredit the witness, which she sees as inhumane to the victims of cross-examination. Tannen takes issue with the adversarial system, suggesting that it can be cruel and distort the truth. For example, she objects to cross-examination of alleged rape victims, as it can distort events to make a rape appear as consensual sex. She also refers to the Anita Hill and Clarence Thomas hearings, arguing that framing the hearings as a two-sided dispute allowed senators to focus on cross-examining Hill rather than seeking other evidence.

As an alternative to the American system, Tannen proposes considering the French and German systems. In the French system, judges do most of the questioning, and lawyers cannot cross-examine witnesses. Guilt is established not by "beyond a reasonable doubt" but by the judge's intimate belief or deeply held sense of what happened. Tannen also recalls a Canadian trial where a Holocaust denier's lawyer interrogated concentration camp survivors, which she sees as an example of the cruelty of cross-examination. However, she does not object to the Canadian hate-speech ban under which the defendant was prosecuted.

Dan is the main character in the input article. He is a man who has undergone extensive surgery after a serious accident involving a collision between a Moon ship and a Mars liner. He is unsure of his identity and struggles to convince his wife, Erica, that he is her husband, Dan Merrol. The story follows Dan as he tries to come to terms with his new appearance and the memories that come with the brain parts he received from the donors.


In the input article, the event where Dan leaves the hospital occurs when he wakes up in a room, feeling alone and wanting to go home. He gets up, reads the chart by his bedside, and searches through the closet for clothes. After dressing himself, he sits down to gain strength and then walks out of the hospital without being stopped by anyone. It is nighttime when he leaves the hospital, and the next thing he remembers is seeing Erica's face as he looks through the door of their home.

In the input article, the doctors let Dan leave the hospital because they believed in Wysocki's theorem, which Dan had invented on the spot. According to the theorem, the patient alone understands what they need, and there are critical times in the recovery of the patient when they should be encouraged to make their own decisions and carry them through by themselves, even though running a slight risk of physical complications. The doctors thought Dan was much stronger than they expected, so when he wanted to go home, they allowed him to do so, following the principles of Wysocki's theorem.

open-answer:
The Phantom Menace is the title of Star Wars Episode 1, a movie directed and written by George Lucas. It is set in the Star Wars universe and features characters such as Jedi Master Qui-Gon Jinn (played by Liam Neeson), Obi-Wan Kenobi (played by Ewan McGregor), Queen Amidala (played by Natalie Portman), and a young Anakin Skywalker (played by Jake Lloyd). The movie's plot revolves around the taxation of trade routes, a trade dispute, and the imminent invasion of the peaceful planet of Naboo. The Phantom Menace is also known for its special effects, including underwater scenes, pod racing, and light-saber battles.

The author of the article has a negative view of The Phantom Menace. They criticize the movie for its stiff dialogue, lack of excitement, and poor direction. The author believes that George Lucas has forgotten how to write and direct a movie, resulting in a film that lacks the "spark of life." They also argue that the actors, despite their talent, are unable to deliver convincing performances due to the poorly written scenes they are given. The author acknowledges that the special effects are impressive but feels that they do not make up for the movie's shortcomings. Overall, the author is disappointed with The Phantom Menace and does not find it as enjoyable or engaging as the original Star Wars trilogy.

According to the author's view in the input article, the reasons behind people liking Phantom Menace are:

1. Emotional investment: Fans have a lot of emotional energy invested in loving the movie and its associated merchandise, which makes them more likely to enjoy it despite its flaws.
2. Nostalgia: The movie plays on people's childhood imagination and memories of the original Star Wars trilogy, making them more likely to enjoy it.
3. Cult movie appeal: Some fans may enjoy the movie because it has a basic story, great special effects, and "stupid dialogue," which can be entertaining in a cult movie.
4. Resistance to critics: Fans may be tired of being told they won't like the movie because it doesn't adhere to certain basic critic criteria, and may enjoy it as a form of defiance against critical opinions.

open-answer:
The Phantom Menace refers to the movie "Star Wars Episode 1: The Phantom Menace," which is the first installment in the prequel trilogy of the Star Wars film series. In the input article, the author discusses the anticipation and excitement surrounding the movie's release, as well as their disappointment with the film's plot, dialogue, and character development. The author criticizes the movie for its lack of excitement, poor writing, and underwhelming performances from the actors. The Phantom Menace serves as the central topic of the article, with the author providing a detailed analysis of the film's shortcomings and expressing skepticism about its potential for long-term success and enjoyment among fans.

The Phantom Menace, as the first episode in the Star Wars timeline, introduces the origins of key characters and sets the stage for the events that unfold in the subsequent movies. Some of the impacts of the Phantom Menace on the Star Wars timeline include:

1. Introducing Anakin Skywalker: The movie presents Anakin as a young slave on Tatooine, who is discovered by Jedi Master Qui-Gon Jinn. Anakin's discovery and eventual training as a Jedi set the stage for his transformation into Darth Vader in later episodes.

2. Establishing the relationship between Obi-Wan Kenobi and Anakin Skywalker: The movie shows the beginning of the mentor-apprentice relationship between Obi-Wan and Anakin, which plays a crucial role in the development of both characters throughout the series.

3. Introducing the concept of the Force and the Jedi Council: The Phantom Menace delves into the concept of the Force and the role of the Jedi Council in maintaining peace and order in the galaxy. This lays the groundwork for the conflict between the Jedi and the Sith that unfolds in later episodes.

4. Introducing key characters and their relationships: The movie introduces characters like Queen Amidala, Jar Jar Binks, and Darth Maul, who play significant roles in the Star Wars universe. It also establishes relationships between these characters and the main protagonists, which develop further in subsequent movies.

5. Setting up the political landscape: The Phantom Menace presents the political landscape of the galaxy, with the Galactic Republic, the Trade Federation, and the Sith all vying for power. This sets the stage for the rise of the Empire and the eventual rebellion against it in later episodes.

6. Establishing the origins of iconic droids: The movie reveals that Anakin Skywalker built C-3PO, which raises questions about the relationship between the droid and Darth Vader in later episodes.

Overall, The Phantom Menace lays the foundation for the Star Wars timeline by introducing key characters, relationships, and concepts that play crucial roles in the development of the story throughout the series.

The author does not seem to be impressed with the implications of The Phantom Menace on the Star Wars timeline. They criticize the movie for being barren of feeling and lacking excitement, even though it introduces key characters, relationships, and concepts. The author questions the logic behind certain plot points, such as Anakin building C-3PO and the relationship between the droid and Darth Vader in later episodes. Overall, the author appears to be disappointed with the movie's execution and its impact on the Star Wars timeline.

open-answer:
"Jan, you're the best driver in Oostpoort," said Dekker. "You will have to take a groundcar to Rathole and bring the fellow back."

"You just don't forget it isn't the Zuider Zee," retorted Heemskerk from the other end. "You sink there and you don't come up three times."

"Don't worry," said Jan. "I'll be back on time, with a broom at the masthead."

"This I shall want to see," chuckled Heemskerk; a logical reaction, considering the scarcity of brooms on Venus.

---

"You must be the man from Oostpoort," said the bearded man, holding out his hand. "I am Doctor Sanchez. We are very grateful you have come."

"I thought for a while I wouldn't make it," said Jan ruefully, removing his venushelmet.

---

"Well, as much as I'd like to stop for a pipe, we'd better start at once," said Jan. "It's a hard drive back, and blastoff can't be delayed."

The woman seemed to sense his meaning. She turned and called: "Diego!"

---

"Who's paying his passage?" he asked. "The Dutch Central Venus Company isn't exactly a charitable institution."

"Your Señor Dekker said that would be taken care of," replied Sanchez.

---

"Who is Diego's father?" he asked.

"He was Ramón Murillo, a very good mechanic," answered Sanchez, with a sliding sidelong glance at Jan's face. "He has been dead for three years."

---

"The copters at Oostpoort can't buck this wind," he said thoughtfully, "or I'd have come in one of those in the first place instead of trying to cross Den Hoorn by land. But if you have any sort of aircraft here, it might make it downwind—if it isn't wrecked on takeoff."

"I'm afraid not," said Sanchez.

---

"Wait," said Sanchez, lifting the scalpel and tilting his head. "I believe there is something, though we cannot use it. This was once an American naval base, and the people here were civilian employes who refused to move north with it. There was a flying machine they used for short-range work, and one was left behind—probably with a little help from the people of the settlement. But...."

"What kind of machine? Copter or plane?"

"They call it a flying platform

Jan was referring to the difficult journey he had just completed to reach Rathole, as well as the challenges he would face on the return trip to Oostpoort with the patient. He had encountered several obstacles, including earthquakes, a howling gale, and a wide chasm that had opened up during his journey. He knew that he would need good luck to successfully navigate these challenges and safely transport the patient back to Oostpoort in time for the G-boat blastoff.

Third, the lawyer would help them draft and present their contract demands to the union. Finally, the lawyer would represent them in court when they faced charges such as breach of contract, malicious mischief, sabotage of the company's machines, and conspiring to destroy the livelihood of the workers.
