Braun, also known as Abner Longmans Braun or "One-Shot" Braun, is a character in the story who is a professional gambler and investor. He has a reputation for having a strong intuition for one-shot gambles and has a history of involvement in various businesses, including insurance and real estate. He has also backed Broadway plays and sponsored beginning actresses as part of his efforts to become more respectable. In the story, he is called upon by the CIA to use his intuition to determine whether an object dropped in the harbor is a bomb or not.


In the input article, the CIA's interest in Braun's career stems from his unique ability to make accurate decisions in one-shot gamble situations. Joan Hadamard, the social science division chief at CIA, has been following Braun's career as a type study in the evolution of "the extra-legal ego." She believes that his transition from a criminal background to a respectable figure is driven by a conflict between his desire for power and his desire for acceptance. This conflict, according to Joan, often leads such individuals to crack under the pressure of trying to appease their conscience.

Braun's ability to make accurate decisions in high-stakes situations is demonstrated when he is asked to determine whether an object dropped in the harbor is a bomb or not. Despite his initial reluctance, Braun ultimately makes the correct decision, proving the value of his intuition in one-shot gamble situations. This ability is seen as crucial by the CIA, as it could potentially save millions of lives in a real bomb-drop scenario. As a result, the CIA considers Braun's involvement in their investigations to be of great importance, and they express their interest in having him as an active part of their team in the future.

Braun's career began as the business manager of an insurance firm that primarily dealt with the International Longshoreman's Association, a racket-ridden union. He later transitioned into professional gambling, focusing on investments, mostly in real estate. He became known as the man who almost bought the Empire State Building. As he aimed for respectability, Braun started backing Broadway plays, sponsoring beginning actresses, and joining playwrights' groups. He also founded an association for clearing the Detroit slum area where he was born. At the time of the story, Braun was considering running for Congress from his district.

The connection between the CIA's interest and Braun's career in the input article lies in his unique ability to make accurate decisions in one-shot gamble situations, which is a valuable skill in high-stakes scenarios.   Everybody knows  him now. Everybody  who passed him on the street knows  him. Everybody who went to the same  schools, or even to different schools  in different towns, knows him now.  Ask them. open-answer:
The hall exploded in angry thunder. The first wave of men rushed onto the stage as Walter stood up. A tomato whizzed past his ear and splattered against the wall. More men clambered onto the stage, shouting and cursing. Walter stood his ground, his face pale but determined.

Suddenly, a voice rang out above the tumult. "Stop!" The crowd froze, and all eyes turned to the man who had spoken. It was Bailey, the shop steward. He climbed onto the stage, his face red with anger. "You fools!" he shouted. "Can't you see what's happening? These men are trying to save our company, and you're letting Torkleson destroy it!"

The crowd began to murmur, and some of the men on the stage hesitated. Bailey continued, his voice rising in passion. "We've been lied to, cheated, and robbed by Torkleson and his cronies. They've taken our company and run it into the ground, all for their own greed. And now they're trying to blame these men for their own failures!"

The crowd's anger began to shift, and they turned their eyes on Torkleson. The union boss tried to speak, but his voice was drowned out by the growing roar of the crowd. The tide had turned, and the workers were no longer willing to be pawns in Torkleson's game.

In the end, the striking managers won their battle. The machines were unlocked, and the company began to rebuild under new leadership. Torkleson and his cronies were ousted, and the workers regained control of their company and their futures. And Walter Towne, the man who had dared to stand up to the powerful union boss, became a symbol of hope and determination for workers everywhere.

The irony in the story lies in the fact that the management, who are traditionally seen as the ones in control and power, are the ones who go on strike against the labor union, which is usually the group that strikes for better working conditions and wages. The roles are reversed, with the labor union now in control of the company and the management struggling to make their voices heard. 

In the end, the management's strike is successful, and they are able to regain some control over the company. This is ironic because strikes are typically associated with labor unions fighting against management, not the other way around. The story highlights the potential consequences of a system where the balance of power is shifted too far in one direction, leading to an unexpected and ironic outcome.

Tin Philosopher is a machine and a member of the managerial board of Puffy Products. He is one of the main characters in the story, participating in the discussions and decision-making processes related to the company's bread products. Tin Philosopher provides a detailed history of bread, highlighting the various advancements in the baking industry. The quest for lighter, whiter bread has been a significant driving force in the evolution of bread-making techniques. The discovery of yeast was a crucial milestone, followed by the process of sifting bran and wheat germ from the flour. Early bleaching and preserving chemicals also played a role in improving the quality of bread.

The vitamin content of wheat germ was a point of contention for some time, but the issue was resolved when tasteless, colorless substitutes were synthesized and introduced into the loaf. This led to the development of bread that was light, airy, and considered the epitome of gustatory excellence.

In the early 21st century, the research of Everett Whitehead, a Puffyloaf chemist, led to the creation of airtight bread that was twenty times stronger (for its weight) than steel and incredibly light. This bread was later exploited by Puffyloaf's competitors, Fairy Bread, with their slogan "It Makes Ghost Toast."

The next significant advancement in bread-making was the substitution of purified carbon dioxide, recovered from coal smoke, for the gas generated by yeast organisms. This made the bread-making process more hygienic and efficient. Finally, Puffyloaf introduced the helium-filled loaf, which was lighter and more appealing to consumers. However, this innovation led to the crisis at the center of the story, as the helium-filled loaves began to float away, causing various problems and challenges for the company.

The reason behind Tin Philosopher telling the history of bread in the input article is to provide context and background information on the development of bread-making techniques, leading up to the introduction of the helium-filled loaf by Puffy Products. This history helps to highlight the significance of the new helium loaf and the continuous quest for lighter, whiter bread throughout human history. Additionally, it serves as a way to engage the other characters in the story and set the stage for the events that follow.

The pumping stations from these lines still exist as relics of Victorian visionaries.

open-answer:
Digital social communities are online platforms where people interact, collaborate, and form connections with others who share their interests. These communities have evolved from early BBSs and the WELL to more recent platforms like blogs, wikis, social bookmarking, music-photo-video sharing, mashups, podcasts, digital storytelling, virtual communities, social network services, virtual environments, and videoblogs. They are characterized by many-to-many communication, active participation of users, and the ability to form social networks that enable broader, faster, and lower-cost coordination of activities.

These communities have the potential to amplify human sociality, including both positive aspects like altruism, fun, community, and curiosity, as well as negative aspects like gossip, conflict, slander, fraud, greed, and bigotry. The design of social media plays a crucial role in enabling or preventing the development of a healthy public sphere and fostering collective action.

Participatory media literacy is essential for individuals to effectively engage in digital social communities and contribute to a participatory culture. This literacy involves the skills to encode and decode knowledge and power through various forms of media, and when learned, introduces individuals to a community. The more people who know how to use participatory media to learn, inform, persuade, investigate, reveal, advocate, and organize, the more likely the future infosphere will allow, enable, and encourage liberty and participation.

In the input article, the author discusses the emergence of cyberculture studies as an interdisciplinary field involving sociologists, anthropologists, historians, psychologists, economists, programmers, and political scientists. The author highlights the abundance of data available for scientific study due to the nature of online sociality, where much of public behavior is recorded and structured in a way that makes it suitable for systematic study. This rich body of data includes every edit on Wikipedia, discussion and talk pages associated with those edits, and billions of Usenet messages. As patterns begin to emerge from this data, researchers are starting to understand what works and what doesn't work with people online, and why. This knowledge can potentially be used to design better social media systems that support human sociality and encourage beneficial collective action.

In the input article, the relationship between digital social communities and their usefulness for scientific study lies in the abundance of data generated by these communities. As people interact, collaborate, and form connections on various online platforms, they create a wealth of information that can be systematically studied by researchers from various disciplines, such as sociology, anthropology, history, psychology, economics, programming, and political science. This rich body of data, which includes edits on Wikipedia, discussion and talk pages, and billions of Usenet messages, allows researchers to identify patterns and understand what works and what doesn't work with people online, and why. By analyzing this data, researchers can potentially design better social media systems that support human sociality, encourage beneficial collective action, and foster a healthy public sphere. This, in turn, emphasizes the importance of participatory media literacy for individuals to effectively engage in digital social communities and contribute to a participatory culture.

1. definition = DEFINE(CTX, "participatory media") : Provide the definition of participatory media given the input article
2. author_definition = FIND_ELEMENT(CTX, "author's definition", "participatory media") : Find the author's definition or explanation of participatory media in the input article
3. ans = CONCAT(definition, author_definition) : Combine the general definition and the author's definition of participatory media to form the final answer
open-answer:
Participatory media refers to a diverse range of digital communication platforms and technologies that enable many-to-many interactions, allowing every person connected to the network to broadcast as well as receive text, images, audio, video, software, data, discussions, transactions, computations, tags, or links to and from every other person. These media are characterized by their social nature, deriving value and power from the active participation of many people, and their ability to link users to each other, forming a public as well as a market. Examples of participatory media include blogs, wikis, RSS, tagging and social bookmarking, music-photo-video sharing, mashups, podcasts, digital storytelling, virtual communities, social network services, virtual environments, and videoblogs. Participatory media literacy is essential for individuals to effectively engage with and contribute to this new media landscape, fostering a participatory culture that promotes freedom, wealth, and resistance against cultural monopolies and enclosure.

Participatory media include (but aren’t limited to) blogs, wikis, RSS, tagging and social bookmarking, music-photo-video sharing, mashups, podcasts, digital storytelling, virtual communities, social network services, virtual environments, and videoblogs. These distinctly different media share three common, interrelated characteristics:

1. Many-to-many media now make it possible for every person connected to the network to broadcast as well as receive text, images, audio, video, software, data, discussions, transactions, computations, tags, or links to and from every other person. The asymmetry between broadcaster and audience that was dictated by the structure of pre-digital technologies has changed radically. This is a technical-structural characteristic.

2. Participatory media are social media whose value and power derives from the active participation of many people. Value derives not just from the size of the audience, but from their power to link to each other, to form a public as well as a market. This is a psychological and social characteristic.

3. Social networks, when amplified by information and communication networks, enable broader, faster, and lower cost coordination of activities. This is an economic and political characteristic.

1. digital_democracy = FIND_ELEMENT(CTX, "concept", "digital democracy") : Find and summarize the concept of digital democracy in the input article
2. main_barrier = FIND_BARRIERS_CAUSES(CTX, "digital democracy") : Find and summarize the main barriers or causes related to digital democracy in the input article
3. author_argument = FIND_ELEMENT(CTX, "author's argument", main_barrier) : Find and summarize the author's argument about the main barrier to digital democracy in the input article
4. ans = CONCAT(digital_democracy, author_argument) : Combine the concept of digital democracy and the author's argument about the main barrier to form the final answer
open-answer:
Digital democracy refers to the idea of using technology, particularly blockchain, to enable new forms of social organization and self-governance. Blockchain, the technology underlying Bitcoin, allows for the creation of secure, transparent records of transactions, which can be applied to communal decision-making. Platforms like Ethereum, Backfeed, and democracy.earth offer ambitious ideas for networked citizenship and decision-making based on blockchain technology. These systems allow for the rapid formation of associations with clear decision processes, enable members to float proposals and discuss them with peers, and can accommodate various decision rules. The vision of digital democracy is one where power is distributed across non-hierarchical assemblies, each lasting just long enough to enact participants' will before dissolving.

The author argues that there are several barriers to digital democracy. These include a sense of failure in conventional democracy, where people feel that traditional practices no longer express the will of the people and only serve the needs of distant elites. There is also a misunderstanding of the term "distributed consensus," which is often misinterpreted in a political context. The emphasis on property rights and ownership in blockchain technology, which underlies digital democracy proposals, may not align with the values of those advocating for a more democratic system. Additionally, the lack of universal access to technology, such as smartphones or other networked devices, prevents full participation in digital democracy. The complexity of blockchain technology also makes it difficult for most people to understand, making it inherently open to potential abuse. Finally, the values underlying blockchain technology may be incompatible with the principles of the commons, which many proponents of digital democracy support.

open-answer:
Rai, full name Amogh Rai, is a 27-year-old Indian ecologist working on a research project titled "Long-term Monitoring of Biomass Stocks and Forest Community Structures in Temperate Zone of Western Himalaya". The project, spearheaded by the non-governmental Centre for Ecology Development and Research (CEDAR) and funded by India's Department of Science and Technology, aims to find out how much carbon is being absorbed by the region's forests. Rai grew up in Delhi and was a tech prodigy before enrolling at Dr. BR Ambedkar University as a master's student. He started working on the project in March 2014.

Kumaon forests are located in the northern Indian foothills of the Himalayas, in the state of Uttarakhand. The area has two main types of oak tree, a number of pines, rhododendrons, cedars, and maples. There are leopards, porcupines, wild boars, a variety of snakes and rodents, and 200 species of butterfly. The forests grow down hillsides into valleys and up along plateaus. The forests of Kumaon are used primarily for fodder and fuel.

Amogh Rai, an ecologist, is collecting data on the forests in Kumaon, a region in the state of Uttarakhand, India, as part of a research project called "Long-term Monitoring of Biomass Stocks and Forest Community Structures in Temperate Zone of Western Himalaya." The project, funded by India's Department of Science and Technology and spearheaded by the non-governmental Centre for Ecology Development and Research (CEDAR), aims to determine how much carbon is being absorbed by the region's forests. Rai uses various tools, such as a ceptometer, a spherical densiometer, and a laser rangefinder, to measure leaf area index, canopy foliage, and tree height. The data collected will be used to create an allometric equation to understand the basic mechanism of carbon sequestration and the level of human disturbance in these forests. This information will then provide the framework for a plan that seeks to pay local people to maintain the forests and preserve their ability to act as a carbon sink.

The research mentioned in the input article includes:

1. The evidence from physics, particularly the relationship between arXiv (the OA repository for physics) and toll-access physics journals, which shows that high levels of green OA don't cause journal cancellations.

plan:
New actions:
- EVALUATE_CONTROL(CTX, X): Evaluate the level of control given to the author by each element in X, based on the input article

1. oa_mandates = FIND_ELEMENT(CTX, "OA mandates", "author control") : Find and summarize all the OA mandates that give the author control over their work in the input article
2. control_levels = EVALUATE_CONTROL(CTX, oa_mandates) : Evaluate the level of control given to the author by each OA mandate in the input article
3. ans = CONCAT(control_levels) : Combine the evaluated control levels of OA mandates to form the final answer for comparing with the options
open-answer:
1. Loophole mandates: These mandates provide a moderate level of control to authors. Authors are required to make their work green OA, but if their publisher does not allow it, they can choose not to deposit their work in the repository or not make it OA. This gives authors some flexibility in deciding whether to make their work OA based on their publisher's policies.

2. Deposit mandates: These mandates offer a lower level of control to authors compared to loophole mandates. Authors are required to deposit their work in an OA repository as soon as it is accepted for publication, regardless of their publisher's OA policies. However, the timing of OA depends on the publisher's permission. If the publisher does not allow OA, the deposited article remains dark or non-OA. If the publisher allows OA, the deposit becomes OA as soon as the permission kicks in. In this case, authors have less control over the OA status of their work, as it depends on their publisher's policies.

3. Rights-retention mandates: These mandates provide the highest level of control to authors. Authors are required to deposit their work in an OA repository as soon as it is accepted for publication, and they secure permission for making the deposit OA through rights retention. This ensures that the university or institution already has the needed permission to make the work OA, and authors do not need to take any special steps to retain rights or negotiate with publishers. Additionally, these mandates offer a waiver option, allowing authors to opt out of the grant of permission to the university, though not out of the deposit requirement. This gives authors more control over the OA status of their work, as they can choose to obtain waivers for specific works if they wish.

open-answer:
Maglev lines, or magnetic levitation systems, were once seen as the future of transportation. The world's first commercial maglev system was opened in Birmingham, UK, in 1984, but it was shut down in 1995 due to technical issues and lack of funding. Germany also had a maglev system called the M-Bahn, which operated in West Berlin from 1989-1991 but was dismantled after the Berlin Wall fell. The German conglomerate Transrapid built a 32km test track for their maglev system, but it now stands idle, and their vehicles are up for auction. 

In Asia, however, maglev technology is still being pursued. Japan began maglev testing in 1962 and is currently building the longest, fastest maglev in the world, the Chūō Shinkansen, which will run at 500km/h and connect Tokyo and Nagoya in just 40 minutes. The first link is scheduled to begin operation in 2027. China is also proposing a 600km/h maglev system between Shanghai and Beijing.

The most difficult aspects and challenges faced by maglev lines in the given input article include:

1. High upfront costs: Maglev is more expensive upfront than high-speed rail, making it difficult to justify its implementation in areas with lower passenger traffic.
2. Limited market: There is a gap in the market for maglev, but there is no market in the gap. Mass transit generally needs more capacity rather than super high speed, which maglev provides.
3. Technological complexity: Maglev systems are more complex than traditional high-speed rail systems, making them harder to maintain and operate.
4. Difficulty in obtaining replacement parts: As maglev systems are unique, it can be challenging to find replacement parts when needed, as was the case with the Birmingham Maglev.
5. Competition with other forms of transportation: Maglev lines face competition from other forms of transportation, such as high-speed rail and, more recently, the proposed Hyperloop technology.

The reasons behind the lack of more maglev lines in the world, as mentioned in the article, include:

1. High upfront costs: Maglev systems are more expensive to build and maintain compared to high-speed rail systems. This makes it difficult to justify their implementation, especially in regions with lower passenger traffic.

2. Complexity: Maglev technology is more complex than traditional rail systems, which can make it harder to develop, maintain, and operate.

3. Lower capacity: Maglev systems generally have lower passenger capacity compared to high-speed rail, making them less suitable for mass transit.

4. Insufficient funding: Many maglev projects in the past, such as the British RTV31 hovertrain, were abandoned due to budget cuts and lack of sufficient funding.

5. Market gap: While there is a gap in the market for high-speed maglev systems, there is no significant market demand for them, as most mass transit systems prioritize increased capacity over super high speed.

6. Competition from high-speed rail: High-speed rail systems have proven to be more cost-effective and practical in many cases, making it difficult for maglev technology to compete.

7. Replacement parts and maintenance: In some cases, such as the Birmingham Maglev, replacement parts became difficult to obtain, leading to the eventual shutdown of the system.

3. ans = CONCAT(distributed_collective_decision, potential_beneficiaries) : Combine the information about the distributed collective decision process and its potential beneficiaries to form the final answer for comparing with the options
open-answer:
A distributed collective decision process is a system that allows groups to make decisions and organize themselves using blockchain technology, which underlies the Bitcoin cryptocurrency. This technology enables the formation of non-hierarchical groups with the ability to act in the world as any state or corporation. It replaces governmental structures at various levels of society with voluntary associations represented as software. Participants in these groups can remain anonymous, but their identities are verified and their votes authenticated by the same processes that secure the Bitcoin network. This creates a permanent, secure record of every vote ever taken, which is available for all to see. The functionality of this system is distributed across the network, making it resistant to state censorship or control.

The direct beneficiaries of a distributed collective decision process are the participants in these groups, who can remain anonymous while having their identities verified and their votes authenticated. This system allows them to form non-hierarchical groups with the ability to act in the world as any state or corporation, replacing governmental structures at various levels of society with voluntary associations represented as software. The functionality of this system is distributed across the network, making it resistant to state censorship or control, and creating a permanent, secure record of every vote ever taken, which is available for all to see.

open-answer:
The project in Kumaon, spearheaded by the non-governmental Centre for Ecology Development and Research (CEDAR) and funded by India's Department of Science and Technology, aims to determine how much carbon is being absorbed by the region's forests. By understanding the basic mechanism of carbon sequestration and the level of human disturbance in these forests, the project can provide the framework for a plan that seeks to pay local people to maintain the forests. If the project can determine how much human interaction with the forest has affected the trees' ability to photosynthesize, then local people can be paid to preserve the forest. The idea is to create something fairly simple that can be executed neatly across a spectrum. A paper will be submitted to the Department of Science and Technology and then a conversation about incentive structures for the local community will begin, using the carbon sequestration data as a basis for what should be offered. There are fears about corruption; and the dispersal of money remains a sketchy and murky affair but, as Rai says, "the idea is that you at least need to get this thing started. If you don't pay people enough to maintain the forest, give me two reasons why they should keep the forests as they are, so that you or I could come and enjoy them? Because they are the ones who have to face the winters here, they are the ones who have to go and work in the forests here." Consultations are ongoing with villagers, various NGOs and the forest department. Once upon a time, the strong social system – the ecologically minded functioning of the rural villages extolled by Gandhi – and dependence on the forest meant the environment was preserved. Now, these things are changing fairly rapidly. The whole idea of working as a social group is getting lost and so, Rai argues, "incentives are going to play a larger role. I've had conversations with people where they've said, 'The forests are great, we want to protect them but we don't have any money.' So it's not just about giving them an incentive to protect the forest, it's that they need money to protect the forest." With the data now collected, allometric equations will determine how much carbon is sequestered in the forests. This information will then be used to put an economic value on the various plots, which will translate into payments made to local communities through the forest councils. This money could begin to pour in within the year.

The Centre for Ecology Development and Research (CEDAR) is working on a project to determine how much carbon is being absorbed by the forests in the Himalayan foothills of India. The project aims to understand the basic mechanism of carbon sequestration and the level of human disturbance in these forests, in order to provide a framework for a plan that seeks to pay local people to maintain the forests. If the project can determine how much human interaction with the forest has affected the trees' ability to photosynthesize, then local people can be paid to preserve the forest. Otherwise, its ability to act as a 'carbon sink' (anything that absorbs more carbon than it releases) risks damage from overuse. The challenge for this project mirrors the challenge faced by climate change scientists and policymakers across the world: how can you reduce fossil fuel emissions and maintain and improve carbon sinks without disrupting or destroying the lives of local people, many of whom will be those most affected by climate change?

The irony between the money locals receive and the preservation of the forest in the input article lies in the fact that while the project aims to pay local people to maintain the forests, this monetary incentive may actually weaken their ties to the forest and reduce their desire to preserve it. The project is based on the idea that if local people are paid to preserve the forest, they will be more likely to do so. However, as the article points out, using the forest less may actually weaken the local people's connection to it, making the desire to preserve it less urgent. This creates a dilemma where the monetization of forest maintenance, which is intended to help preserve the forest, may actually have the opposite effect by reducing the local people's attachment to the forest and their motivation to protect it.

open-answer:
The Lancet, an Elsevier journal, published an editorial in October 2004 that disagreed with the Association of American Publishers President Patricia Schroeder's claim that widening access to research through green OA mandates would bring the edifice of scientific publishing crashing down. The editorial stated, "Schroeder provides no evidence that it would do so; she merely asserts the threat. This style of rebuttal will not do."

In the given quote, The Lancet, an Elsevier journal, expresses disagreement with Patricia Schroeder, the President of the Association of American Publishers, regarding her claim that increasing access to research through green open access (OA) mandates would cause the collapse of scientific publishing. The editorial argues that Schroeder's claim lacks evidence and is based solely on her assertion of the threat. The Lancet criticizes this approach, stating that such a rebuttal is insufficient and unconvincing.

The context of this quote is a discussion on the potential impact of green OA policies on toll-access journal subscriptions. The article explores various factors and evidence related to this issue, including the experience of physics journals with high levels of green OA, publisher incentives to maintain subscriptions, and the potential benefits of OA for submissions and subscriptions. The Lancet's editorial highlights the need for a more evidence-based approach to the debate on the effects of green OA mandates on scientific publishing.

2. oa_policy_use = FIND_EVENT(CTX, "strong OA policy put into use") : Find and summarize all the events where a strong OA policy is put into use in the input article
3. oa_policy_impact = FIND_IMPACTS(CTX, oa_policy_use) : Find and summarize the impacts or outcomes of a strong OA policy being put into use in the input article
4. ans = CONCAT(oa_policy, oa_policy_use, oa_policy_impact) : Combine the information about strong OA policy, its usage, and its impacts to form the final answer for comparing with the options
open-answer:
A strong OA (Open Access) policy in the input article refers to policies that require or seem to require Open Access for research articles. There are three approaches to strong OA policies at universities: 

1. Loophole mandates: These require green OA (Open Access through repositories) except when the author's publisher doesn't allow it. 
2. Deposit mandates: These require deposit in an OA repository as soon as the article is accepted for publication, but they separate the timing of deposit from the timing of OA. If the author's publisher doesn't allow OA, then these policies keep the deposited article dark or non-OA. 
3. Rights-retention mandates: These require deposit in an OA repository as soon as the article is accepted for publication, just like deposit mandates. But they add a method to secure permission for making the deposit OA. There's more than one way to secure that permission, such as retaining the nonexclusive right to authorize OA through a repository.

It is important to note that none of these mandates absolutely require OA, as they all have some level of flexibility, such as allowing some work to escape through the loophole, allowing some deposited work to remain dark, or offering waiver options for authors.

1. Faculty voting for a rights-retention OA mandate with a waiver option: Faculty votes tend to be overwhelming or unanimous when a waiver option is available in a rights-retention OA mandate.
2. Institutions adopting the strongest OA policies they can: Institutions should adopt the strongest OA policies they can today and watch for the moment when they could strengthen them.
3. Institutions seizing opportunities to strengthen their OA policies: Institutions should watch the shifting balance of power and seize opportunities to strengthen their OA policies as circumstances change.
4. Every strong new policy increasing the likelihood of publisher accommodation: Every strong, new OA policy creates some of the conditions of its own success by increasing the likelihood of publisher accommodation.
5. Every institution adopting a new policy brings about OA for the research it controls: Every institution adopting a new OA policy makes the way easier for other institutions behind it and helps accelerate publisher adaptation.

1. Faculty voting for a rights-retention OA mandate with a waiver option: When a waiver option is available in a rights-retention OA mandate, faculty votes tend to be overwhelming or unanimous, indicating strong support for such policies.

2. Institutions adopting the strongest OA policies they can: By adopting the strongest OA policies possible, institutions can help remove access barriers to research and contribute to the growth of OA literature.

3. Institutions seizing opportunities to strengthen their OA policies: As circumstances change and more institutions adopt OA policies, institutions should watch the shifting balance of power and seize opportunities to strengthen their OA policies, further promoting OA and its benefits.

4. Every strong new policy increasing the likelihood of publisher accommodation: Each strong, new OA policy creates some of the conditions of its own success by increasing the likelihood of publisher accommodation, making it easier for other institutions to adopt similar policies.

5. Every institution adopting a new policy brings about OA for the research it controls: By adopting new OA policies, institutions not only make their own research more accessible but also make it easier for other institutions to follow suit, helping to accelerate publisher adaptation and the overall growth of OA literature.

open-answer:
Coworking spaces in the input article refer to shared office spaces that cater to freelancers, startups, and even large corporations. These spaces provide a flexible and collaborative work environment, often featuring a mix of open work areas, private offices, and communal facilities. They are designed to encourage networking, creativity, and a sense of community among their members. Coworking spaces have become increasingly popular due to the rise of the gig economy, corporate downsizing, and the desire for more social connection in the workplace. Examples of coworking spaces mentioned in the article include Second Home, WeWork, and The Trampery.

Some direct benefits of coworking spaces mentioned in the article include: 
- Access to a community of like-minded individuals and businesses, leading to networking opportunities and collaborations.
- A flexible and scalable workspace that can grow with the business.
- A curated environment that can enhance the company's brand and image.
- Access to events and workshops that can provide intellectual support and learning opportunities.
- A more enjoyable and social work environment compared to traditional office spaces.
- Access to shared resources and amenities, such as fast Wi-Fi, power sockets, and kitchen facilities.
- Opportunities for serendipitous encounters and connections with people from different industries and backgrounds.

open-answer:
The coworking spaces mentioned in the article include Second Home, WeWork, Timberyard, and The Trampery. Second Home is known for its exuberant architecture and collaborative culture, attracting businesses such as Bulb, TaskRabbit, and ASAP54. WeWork, on the other hand, is a more corporate coworking space with a focus on providing a sense of community and services for its members. Timberyard is a coffee shop-workspace hybrid that offers a more ad hoc workspace for mobile workers, with fast Wi-Fi, power sockets, and artisan-produced food. The Trampery is a pioneering coworking organization in London that specializes in different sectors such as fashion, retail, travel, and tourism. It is also moving into co-living spaces with its upcoming Fish Island Village project in Hackney Wick.

Second Home cares about exuberant architecture, collaborative culture, and attracting a diverse range of businesses. Some features include sweeping curved walls, a wide cantilevered staircase, colorful interiors, and a variety of plants and flowers. Second Home also hosts events to help members network and offers intellectual support.

WeWork focuses on providing a sense of community and services for its members. It offers a more corporate coworking space with features such as raw concrete interiors, exposed ceilings, multicolored upholstery, a kitchen with an island bar, easy chairs and sofas, tables of varying heights and sizes, music, and recreational facilities like table tennis tables.

Timberyard is a coffee shop-workspace hybrid that offers a more ad hoc workspace for mobile workers. Its features include fast Wi-Fi, plentiful power sockets, careful temperature regulation, natural light, attentive design, and artisan-produced food. Timberyard is designed to encourage customers to stay and work in a comfortable environment.

The Trampery is a pioneering coworking organization in London that specializes in different sectors such as fashion, retail, travel, and tourism. It focuses on creating intentional communities and securing corporate partnerships. The Trampery is also moving into co-living spaces with its upcoming Fish Island Village project in Hackney Wick, which will include communal spaces and a mix of social housing and coworking spaces.
